titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. On rising this morning I found my thermometer below ten degrees of frost, and the weather being fine I walked before breakfast. Visits from Mr Montreal, and Mr Woodward— The Ladies went out with Mr Smith to the ice-hills— Catherine went and passed the Evening at Madame Colombi’s.— Mr Magnitzky was the other person arrested at the same time with Speransky, and the rumour is that ten or twelve other persons have had the same fortune— Speransky was Secretary General of the Empire; and very lately in high favour with the Emperor— Magnitzky was also a member of the Council and a Secretary for the Department of Legislation— He had a few months since received a red ribband— The cause assigned for their present misfortune is said to be the discovery of a treasonable Correspondence— But probably this is mere Conjecture.

2. Mr Woodward was here this morning. The Ladies went with Mr Fisher and Mr Ingraham, and saw the glass manufactory and also the Church of St: Alexander Nevsky. Miss Frederica Bode, Mr Fisher and Mr Ingraham dined with us, and spent the Evening— Mr Montreal paid me an Evening visit— Charles was unwell with a stiff-neck, caught yesterday at the ice-hills.— His state of health abridges his lessons, and retards his progress— I have now only the morning for my own reading, for every Evening is taken up by Charles or by visitors— I am still reading Paucton, whose scriptural, Hebrew, Greek and Roman measures, differ so materially from those stated in my English Bible, that I scarcely know upon which of the two to credit.

3. The weather began at length to moderate, and first began this day to thaw— It snowed however all the morning. I pass’d the day without interruption; and walked before dinner— In the Evening we had Cards— After the weights and measures I have come to the part of Paucton’s Book which treats of Coins— He cites many of the antient Classics, and the Bible continually; but it is impossible to reconcile the statements of the various authorities together, and he sometimes proposes a various reading, sometimes charges his authority with inaccuracy, error, and even worse, with stupidity or want of critical acumen, sometimes hazards his own conjectures, and often resorts to the confusion which has arisen from the practice of calling different things by the same name— This has been indeed the source of infinite errors and innumerable difficulties— The term pound for example in English, designates three different measures—the pound avoirdupoise—the pound Troy, and the pound sterling— Of these, the pound sterling has varied in quantity and value through a succession of ages and has meant at one time one thing and another at another— When the practice of calling the measures of one Country by the names belonging to different measures of another is added the confusion increases— Thus English writers speak of the French Pint and Bushel, though the Pinte held more than two English Pints, and the Boisseau less than 1/3 of the Bushel. But with the fashion of writing down numbers in antient manuscripts, the imperfect knowledge we can have of what any of their measures were compared with our standards, and the ignorance and errors of the writers themselves, it becomes perhaps an inextricable labyrinth— I adhere however to the study of Paucton; and this day again lost the hours for writing by abandoning them to him.

4. Mr Saltus and Mr Delprat of New-York, just arrived here with him from Riga paid me a morning visit— Catherine and Mr Smith spent the Evening at General Betancourt’s— In my walk I met the Chevalier Brancia, on the Fontanka. The first thing he said to me, was a question what I thought of the affair of Speransky— I did not exactly tell him all I thought of it— I wrote nothing this day— But having found in Paucton a table of specific gravities marking a difference of nearly 1 1/2 per Cent in the weight of distilled water and river or well water, and of about 6/1000 between these and rain Water, I compared the weights of two of them by an experiment— I weighed the same bottle full of Neva Water, and then of Snow Water melted by the warmth of this day’s air— Their weight was exactly the same; but the river Water was at a temperature of 7 or 8 degrees, and the snow Water at 2 or 3.— The French kilogram is a weight of distilled water at a temperature of 3 degrees 3/10 of Réaumur which was ascertained to be that of the maximum of Water’s density, and it was weighed in vacuo— Paucton’s table gives 69. french pounds for the weight of a cubic foot, french, of distilled water in summer and 69.56 in Winter— He takes 69.28 as the weight of a mean temperature— Lalonde says that a cubic foot of distilled water at 10. degrees of Reaumur, weighs 69.89. and at 20 degrees of heat would weigh 878 grains less— According to the definitive French metrical system, the Cubic French foot is assumed at 70.02424.— Now if according to Paucton’s tables the same quantity of Rain Water weighs 1/2 a pound, and River or Well Water, a whole pound more, a proportional allowance must be made for the weight of the Water that I have to weigh.— My experiments and my Calculations wasted the whole day.

5. Mr Fisher came this morning and informed me that Mr Fluck would go in two or three days for London, and would take letters. Prince Koslofsky paid us a visit yesterd this Evening; having yesterday received the chamberlain’s key. Mr Smith dined abroad— Both our Children are very unwell, and Charles has a violent and obstinate cough— I read this day the remaining Chapters of the first part of Watts’s improvement of the mind. The 17th: Chapter, on improving the Memory, is precisely on the subject of one of my lectures, and contains so many of the same thoughts, that any impartial reader of my Lecture would certainly suspect me of having borrowed freely from the Doctor.— I never read that chapter of his Book untill this day— Almost all his observations are just, but there is occasionally an ejaculation of piety, which he might as well have omitted— His argument against Shaftesbury’s test of ridicule as applicable to sacred subjects is decisive; and his comparison of the principle with that of persecution is very just and ingenious. The Chapter on the Sciences and their use in the Professions is full of sound sense and solid instruction. The caution against wasting time upon studies very laudable in themselves, but which cannot be pursued without encroaching upon necessary occupations, I feel at this moment with peculiar force. If I do not profit by the advice my fault will be the greater— The recommendation of poetry has the warm sensibility of a Poet— The opinion that Epic Poetry would have been more perfect if interspersed with Elegiac and Lyric Odes, may be controverted; but that it would have rendered the Poems of Homer, Virgil, Tasso and Milton more interesting I do fully believe— The advice to young men of lively genius and a poetical turn to
write poetry, if they cannot possibly help it has some pretension to pleasantry.— I read also the Sermons 14. and 15. Vol 5. of the English preacher—on Subjection to Civil Authority, and on the Crown of Righteousness for Christian Fortitude— This morning I read from Levit: XX to XXV and particularly fixed by attention upon Chapter 23. containing the directions for the several feast days prescribed to the Jews— They were the Sabbath—every seventh day throughout the year— The Passover—the feast of unleavened bread, which was the day after; when the first fruits of the Harvest, a wheat sheaf was offered, and unleavened bread was to be eat seven days—the Pentecost, fifty days after, when loaves of Bread, from the new Harvest were offered— The feast of trumpets the first day of the seventh Month, when the beginning of the Civil year was proclaimed— The feast of atonement or expiation, when the scape-goat Hazazel was sent abroad—the tenth day of the 7th: month— And the feast of tabernacles, beginning the 15th of the 7th: Month, and lasting seven days; during which the People were to dwell in Booths— The Sabbath, has been adopted, (only with a change of the day) by all Sects of Christians— The Passover and Pentecost, by almost all— The three others have been considered as abolished by the Christian dispensation— The Jubile was proclaimed on the expiation day, every fiftieth year— The Jubile was an excellent institution, which operated at once as an agrarian Law, and a Law against Slavery— The tenure of lands was equivalent at most to a lease for fifty years, nor could the service of a Hebrew be engaged for a longer term. The precept to let the lands lay fallow every seventh-year, and again on the year of Jubile, is more difficult to account for, and in mere human institutions could not be admitted— I do not recollect that in the subsequent history of the Nation there is any notice of its effects.

6. Walking out this morning I met Count Romanzoff, who asked me if I had received a Courier from Paris—I had not— He said that Prince Kurakin had given him notice that he had furnished a Courier’s Passport to a Mr Smith at the request of Mr Barlow— That the Prince had been asked for a Passport for the Gentleman to come into Russia; but not having the right to give it, he had concluded to give him at once a Courier’s Passport, and to apologize for it to this Government.— He the Count had entirely approved of this, and had mentioned the circumstance even to the Emperor, who had also approved it— This was nearly a Month ago— He asked me whether it was the same Mr Smith who had been here before— I knew nothing of the whole matter, and could not tell him— The Count told me that he had received a letter from General Van Suchtelen who is gone to Sweden, and who had been detained on the island of Aland, by the impossibility of crossing the gulph— He had at length pass’d, and had written to the Count by the boatman who took him over; but he had been obliged to leave his equipage, and even all his baggage behind.— I also twice met Prince Koslofsky, who walked with me about half an hour— The Ladies Mr Smith and myself dined at Mr Fisher’s— The Anderson, Krehmer and Venning families were there, Admiral Gregg, Captain Guedes and some other Gentlemen— We came home early in the Evening— I had been nearly two hours in bed, when I was called up by my wife, who was in extreme alarm, owing to a violent bleeding at the nose, and she thought at the mouth, which followed a severe and sudden fit of coughing, with which Charles had awaked— I sent immediately for Dr: Galloway, who came soon after and assured me, that the bleeding was only one of the symptoms of a catarrhal Cough, and had nothing in it to excite uneasiness— Mrs Adams herself was excessively ill, for two or three hours— I was too much affected by the scene— Too much, because I had neither composure of mind nor physical strength left, adequate to the occasion— I pray God, that not even my Affection for my wife and children, may deprive me of that self-possession most necessary, upon the severest trials— That it may not at moments of danger to them, disqualify me for the exertion by which alone they may be assisted or relieved. I often think that an excessive attachment to my children may be an offense in the eye of Heaven, and dread that they may be taken from me for my punishment— For their preservation, and for the improvement of my own Fortitude, I have no reliance but on the blessing of Providence— Between three and four this morning I retired again to my bed, my wife and child being both in some measure recovered, and quieted to rest. Catherine whose attendance to them was kind and affectionate left them after me.

7. Charles appears this day to be much better, but the infant was very unwell— I took myself a severe Cold, which was troublesome all this day— Mr Andrew and Mr Cutts called on me this morning— Mr Cutts wished for a decision by the Minister of Commerce, concerning the admission of certain goods from Cadix which had no regular Certificate of Origin— Mr Montreal likewise paid me a morning visit— I received from Count Romanzoff a written Notification that Prince Kurakin had advised him that at the request of Mr Barlow he had furnished a Courier’s Passport to Mr John Smith, who was charged with dispatches for me.— I spent the Evening with Charles and at Cards.

8. I was so unwell the whole day as to be in a great measure disqualified for any useful occupation, and in a manner the most irksome listlessness which prompts to indolence without excusing it— I walked nevertheless—looked in for half an hour at the auction of Books,
and afterwards walking on the Fontanka met Mr Woodward who walked with me— We had Evening visits from Mr: Rosenzweig and Mr Brandel who had a budget of news.— I wrote to Mr Russell in London— My indisposition has suspended much of my attention to the Books I am reading—to Paucton among the rest.

9. Morning visit from Mr Woodward— My Landlord Mr Strugowshikoff also came, and proposed to me a Country-house for a Summer residence; on the Peterhoff road, and 15 Versts distant from the City— I told him I did not expect to go out of the City next Summer— In my walk before dinner I met the Emperor who spoke to me of nothing but the weather— Said that we should have a very late Spring, which would appear still later from the earliness of that of the last year— That the floods would be extraordinarily high when the rivers would break up, the late snows having been so considerable— It had been snowing all the morning— The Emperor is to leave his Capital in two days, to join his army— His manner to day was graver and less cheerful than I have usually seen him. Mr Woodward paid us a second visit in the Evening; which we spent mostly at Cards— I took a warm foot bath before going to bed; to relieve my Cold, which is yet severe— But it did not this day prevent me either from reading or writing— I proceed in the perusal of Paucton’s Olla Podrida— Who from the Roman Weights and Coins makes only one step to a dissertation upon Usury, antient and modern— Calculations of Annuities, Insurance, Exchange, Tare and Tret— It is a curious Work, but the further I proceed, the more distrustful I become of his accuracy.

10. Visits from Mr Montreal, Mr Saltus and Mr Harris— Mr Saltus came to complain of the merchants who have done his business in Riga; who have made out as he says unjust and false accounts of charges against him, and who after he has paid them entirely all their demands refuse to deliver to him his property deposited with them, but upon Condition that he will give them a written acknowledgment that their accounts are right.— Mr Montreal was apologizing for not delivering up to Mr Woodward, some property belonging to Mr Gray, which the house have had nearly a year in their possession— I requested Mr Harris to mention to Mr Meyer, my wish to draw on Amsterdam, for the amount of exigencies to meet the contingency of War between France and Russia, which is now unavoidable.— I was confined the whole of this day to the house, by the violence of the Cold I have taken, and by Dr: Galloway’s advice took medicine— Mrs Adams, was also very unwell this morning— Charles and the infant, Catherine and Mr Smith are all more or less indisposed— The Winter ends as it began, by general illness throughout the house— I have lived through one such Winter before— The Chevalier de Bray, and his Lady, paid us a short Evening visit— Mrs Adams and Catherine took an Evening ride.

11. Morning visit from Mr Bentzon, who informed me that he could not obtain the object of his expedition to this Country, and that he intended to go in about a week— Mr Smith and myself dined at the Chevalier de Bray’s, with a small Company— Count Bussche and Mr Lebzeltern were the only members of the diplomatic Corps there; but Count St: Julien and Baron Blome came in after dinner— I returned home very early, being still afflicted with the Cattarrhal Cold and Cough, that I have had these five days— We finished the Evening with Cards.

12. Mr Ecky paid me a visit this morning, and took his Passport— He intends leaving this City for Vienna in about ten days.— I walked before dinner to the Foundery— The weather is fine and mild, but the Streets bad for walking— This is the first day that wears the appearance of the breaking up of Winter.— I finished reading the second part of Watts’s Improvement of the Mind, and began his discourse on the Education of Children and Youth. The second part is on the Communication of useful knowledge—much shorter than the first, and not equal to it.— Watts was a dissenting clergyman— He is cautious never to say any thing that could give offence to the established Church, but he indulges his passion with so much the more freedom against the Roman Catholics— With transsubstantiation it seems as if he never would finish— He insists strongly upon the distinction between things above reason, which as mysteries of religion, may and ought to be believed, and things contrary to religion, which he says must be false: but I doubt whether this distinction will avail, for the maintenance of any religious creed— For any part of the Christian faith I am persuaded it will not.— The Trinity, the Divinity of Christ, the whole Doctrine of Atonement, all Miracles, the immaculate conception of Jesus, and a devil maintaining War against Omnipotence appear to me all as contrary to human reason as the real presence of the Eucharist— Religion as it appears to me is one of the Wants of human Nature— An appetite which must be indulged; since without its gratification human existence would be a burden rather than a blessing— Reason may serve as a guard and check upon the religious appetite as well as upon our bodily necessities, to prevent its leading us into pernicious excesses— But it is presumption in human reason to set itself up as the umpire of our faith— My own Reason is as fallible as that of the Pope—and probably much more so than the collective Reason of an Ecclesiastical Council— I cannot reject a doctrine merely because my Reason will not sanction it— I must appeal to a higher tribunal; and
believe, what I want to believe; am taught to believe, and may believe without injury to myself or others— The argumentum ex absurdo, is conclusive only upon subjects of a finite nature— Excellent for Mathematics and Geometry, but incompetent for infinity— It is not the absurdity of the doctrine of transubstantiation that proves its error, but as I conceive it is its pernicious tendencies; to enslave the human mind; to subject it to the arbitrary dominion of the priesthood—weak, corrupt and fallible men like ourselves.— Could I once bring myself to believe that by a special power from Heaven, a Priest can turn a wafer into a God and a Cup of Wine into the Blood of my Redeemer, the next and natural step would be to believe that my eternal weal or woe depended upon the fiat of the same Priest— That the keys of Heaven were in his hands to lock and unlock at his pleasure, and that the happiness or misery of my existence in the world to come, depended upon the chance of propitiating not the Deity but his Minister— All these tenets of the Romish Church are streams from the fountain of transubstantiation— The doctrine is pernicious—one motive for disbelieving it— Then I may examine it by the test of Reason— The doctrine is not necessary for the general system of Christianity— It is countenanced by the letter of Christs Words Matt: XXVI.26. Mark XIV.22. Luke XXII.19. (In St: John’s Gospel it is not at all mentioned as an occurrence at the last Supper, but with much more detail upon another occasion. John VI.26–66.) and it appears that the words when spoken even by himself shocked his disciples so much, that many of them, from that time; walked no more with him—though he told them by way of explanation that “his words were Spirit”—that is, as I believe—that they were to be understood in a spiritual, or figurative sense— This of itself is sufficient to settle the question in my mind— If the words were figurative there is no real presence— If they were not—if he performed a miracle, and the bread and wine of the last Supper were really his flesh and his blood, it does not follow that the same miracle can be repeated by every Priest, at every Commemmoration of that Event— He promises no such thing— I trace the Doctrine therefore directly to Priestcraft, to the obvious purpose of the Priests to establish their dominion over the minds of Men, under the mask of holy Mystery— I see that by the History of Christianity such has been its effects— That its consequences have been anti-christian in the highest degree—and that it is a mystery above though not contrary to my reason, why Divine Providence has permitted the weakness and folly of men to turn the very words of Christ to such dreadful abuses— Such is my opinion of transubstantiation— Its abstract inconsistency with my reason is not my principal ground for disbelieving it— The Doctor’s remarks upon preaching are as his Editors remark partly out of date. There is some Satirical humour in them— His principles respecting the influence of human authority are a little embarrassed about the settlement of a difficult boundary— The Chapters on writing Books for the Public and on writing and reading Controversies, are mere loose thoughts scarcely skimming the surface— But the active, thinking and judicious mind appear in them all— I read also Sermons 4 and 5 Vol. 6. of the English preacher—on the unenviable condition of the Wicked; and the wisdom of regarding Counsel. This was my Son George’s birth-day, and brought again the grateful recollection of the joy, which this day eleven years ago, brought me.— Laus Deo— May it never be obliterated from my heart! Charles 3. f 3 1/2 i.

13. Morning visit from Mr Harris—while he was here I received a packet from Count Romanzoff, enclosing one from Paris, forwarded by a Russian Courier through Vienna; it was from a Mr John W. Smith an Agent of Coll: Thorndike’s of Boston, the person as I now suppose for whom Mr Barlow had obtained a Courier’s Passport from Prince Kurakin— The principal Contents were a large packet to be delivered to Mr Plummer— Mr Harris offered immediately to take it with him; and took it accordingly— It snowed almost the whole day; thawing very much at the same time— I was therefore confined to the house; we had Cards untill late in the Night.— I recover slowly from the sharp Catarrh and Cold that I have had a full week.

14. I went with the Sleigh and one horse to Mr Meyer’s and requested him to negotiate for me bills upon Amsterdam, which I am obliged to do at a loss of about 20 per Cent, but as there is at present every probability that in a few weeks the exchange itself will be entirely cut off, I am compelled to draw not only for the supply of my immediate wants, but in advance as far as I can without coming to any actual anticipation upon the public funds— As this will give me a considerable sum on hand, which I do not think it prudent to keep, either in Bank Bills or in Specie, I consulted Mr Meyer, on the means of placing it at some use by which it might be realized as I shall have occasion for it—and by his advice determined to place it partly in Bank Obligations bearing an interest of five per Cent, and the rest in Bills of the Silver-loan— In all this I proceed with some embarrassment, and unavoidable loss— But it is what I believe most prudent for the provision necessary to support the current expences of
my family— I paid a visit to Count Löwenhielm at the Hotel de l’Europe— I had an hour’s Conversation with him, on political affairs— He thinks the failure of the Turkish Peace ascribable to the Chancellor, with whom I think he is not satisfied— His opinions respecting France seem tinctured with prejudices. The War he holds impossible to be avoided, and at the same time thinks it will not take place if the Emperor Alexander consents to a personal meeting with Bonaparte. I walked round the Quay and Fontanka; the Spring thaws are just setting in; a full month later than last year. Spent the Evening with Charles and at Cards.

15. Went with Mrs Adams to the sale of furniture, porcelain and Books at Hemilian the jeweller’s— Etter came to shew us a necklace of stones engraved—all antiques— He asked 5000 Rubles for it, and said he had given four.— Mr Harris paid us a long visit in the Evening.

16. Rode in the sleigh to the Russian Bookseller’s shop, and purchased two French, Geographical and Commercial Dictionaries— After which as I was walking the round I met Mr Prevôt; who turned and walked with me— He is going in a few days as a Courier,—I asked him to take a small packet for me; which he promised to do with pleasure; but said he did not expect to go to Paris— He should go directly to the Emperor, (Napoleon) who will in all probability have left Paris, before he, Prevôt can arrive there.— I stop’d for a few minutes at the sale of Books— Soon after I returned home, Mr Plummer came in, with Mr John W. Smith, the expected Courier from Paris— He brought me a letter of introduction from Coll Thorndike, a short letter from Mr Barlow, one from Mr F. C. Gray, and one from my Mother to my wife, dated in November last. The rest of his packets which were very large, were addressed to himself, and enclosed under cover to me by way of securing them— He says that on his way he pass’d through different bodies of troops: amounting to not less than 150,000 men— The french Imperial Guards before he got out of the French Territory—Westphalian troops 25000 men at Wittenberg; and 15000 men of french troops entered Berlin, the day after he arrived there— He complains of being very ill—apparently with a consumption— I sent this morning to Mr Fisher for an account, he has had for some time against me, and in the course of the day received it. Madame Bezerra was here the first part of the Evening, and Madame de Betancourt and her daughters the latter part of it— I spent most of it, amusing and teaching Charles

17. I rose between 6 and 7 this morning, and employed the time untill breakfast, as I ought always to employ it; reading and writing. After breakfast I went and attended the auction of Books to no purpose— Walking, I met and walked with the Chevalier Brancia, who told me that the Swedish Courier lately arrived came with information that the Austrian Minister at Stockholm, had communicated to the Swedish Government an Alliance offensive and defensive between his Court and that of France, with the offer to Sweden of the liberty of acceding to it, and a demand upon the Swedish Government to take its side— Prevost told me yesterday that Count St: Julien had been saying to People, who had not been backward in reporting it, that his Government was trop sage pour s’allier à la France— Brancia told me some time ago that Austria was making her Minister here, Count St: Julien, jouer un rôle fort sot—and he this day reminded me of that remark. It is certain he has been all along talking neutrality and announcing it officially; while the alliance has been concluding at Paris, and now is divulged by the way of Sweden— I also met in my walk Mr Harris, Mr Nancarro, Mr Ingraham, and a multitude of other persons Ladies, and Gentlemen— Among the rest General Pardo, who has been very ill, and Mr Lebzeltern, who as Brancia remarked seemed to be shy of us— The Ladies paid an Evening visit at Madame de Bray’s, and spent the rest of the Evening with Madame Bezerra. Charles and I were learning to read numbers— Messrs: Meyer and Brüxner sent me a second draft upon Amsterdam, and the stock of the silver loan— Upon reflection I think it most prudent to postpone for some days the third draft that I had intended.

18. I called this morning upon Mr Meyer; paid him the balance of the house’s Account against me—left with him a letter of advice to the Willinks and Van Staphorsts at Amsterdam, and informed him of my determination to postpone for the present my third draft— I called afterwards upon the French Ambassador, and conversed with him about an hour— He was not sparing in his observations upon the impolicy of the Russian Cabinet in accepting a Prussian Province at the Peace of Tilsit— A province taken from their own allies— He thought it equally impolitic in the last Peace between France and Austria, that Russia had accepted the 400,000 Souls in Gallicia, by a Cession from Austria— Russia he said was always temporizing; always on the watch for expedients; never ready to take a decisive part— If Russia had seriously and energetically threatened Austria she would have prevented the last War between Austria and France— If she had now seriously threatned Sweden, there would not have been the danger
of the present War— When several powers were engaged in a common Cause they must be responsible for one another,—he did not know for what Russia was going to War— They said it was not for the duchy of Oldenburg— Count Romanzoff was certainly desirous of Peace; but they would not give any explanations— The Emperor Alexander had declared he would send Count Nesselrode to Paris— It had not been asked of him— It was his own determination— Nesselrode had merely been a Secretary of Embassy— He was to have returned to Paris in the same capacity— It had been announced to all Europe that he was to be sent— Yet he had not been sent— Chernicheff had been sent here with a letter from the Emperor Napoleon himself— This letter it was admitted manifested pacific at least if not amicable dispositions— Yet five or six weeks had been suffered to pass before any answer to it had been sent— As to Austria, he himself had witnessed how they felt towards Russia— He had been at Vienna at the time of the marriage— He arrived there five days before the Prince of Neufchatel— From the moment of his arrival, Count Schuvaloff, who was then the Russian Envoy was deserted— Nobody would go near him— But he, Lauriston, walked about with him arm in arm, to get him better treatment. The Austrian Officers all told him they hoped soon to have in concert with France a War against Russia— In Prussia too, they had talked to him about Russia’s having accepted at Tilsit one of their Provinces—taken from their own ally!— How could Russia expect friends in those quarters?— I mentioned to him the Duke of Bassano’s late Report to the Emperor Napoleon, and told him that the British Ministry now adhered to their orders in Council, as I believed only because they thought they would produce this War between France and Russia— He said that as to the Principle in the Duke of Bassano’s Report, that vessels navigating under an Enemy’s Convoy must be considered as Enemies, there could be no doubt of that— But then Circumstances were to be taken into Consideration— The necessity of having some trade; the impossibility of having any if all convoyed vessels were excluded, all this was ground for discussion, explanation, Negotiation—and that was what Russia now withheld— I also called upon General Pardo, who is yet weak, recovering from a severe nervous fever. His opinions run in a very different channel from those of the Ambassador— He says the Treaty was signed by Prince Schwartzenberg the 14th: of March—a renewal of the Treaty of 1758.— That it was communicated to Sweden, with certain offers, and instantly rejected; Sweden immediately gave the information to Russia— And as it was expected by the Emperor Alexander, it will have no effect whatsoever on his measures— Austria is in too bad a condition herself for a serious War, and hates the French too much to join cordially with them— The General was bitter in his remarks upon Count Metternich, the Austrian prime Minister, who he says does not care a straw for the real interests of Austria— I visited at the Chevalier de Bray’s, but he was abroad— Walked an hour— Evening at home, with Charles and at Cards.

19. Long morning visit from Count Bussche, who is in no small perplexity how to get home, with his family of three young daughters— He knows not when he shall receive his orders, to go, and is apprehensive he may be obliged to pass through both the armies in the midst of the campaign. He told me he had seen the written report of the Conversation, the Emperor Alexander had one day last Summer with Mr Schenbom who had then just returned from Sweden— And that the Emperor then had told Schenbom, he should have no objection to their taking Norway— It snowed great part of this day, and I was out of the house only for a short walk. I finished reading Watts’s Discourse on the Education of Children and Youth— He gives a contrasted description of the excessive rigour and severity with which children had been usually brought up, about a Century before he wrote, and of the most profuse and unlimited liberty indulged to children in his age— Watts died before the middle of the last Century; and this Discourse must have been written some years before his death— The indulgence of fashionable education has become much more profuse and unlimited than it was when he complained of it as excessive, and it is much to be wished it were turned again towards rigour— Not perhaps to the extreme of the seventeenth Century; but to much more than I am able to practice. Watts himself inclines to the system of severity, and from my own experience I concur altogether in the opinion, with him.— The Sections upon Self-Government, on collecting rules of Prudence, and on the Sports and Diversions of Children— He undervalues I think the Languages, both antient and modern— But the course of my life has probably led me to overrate them— He prohibits Plays, Masquerades, Assemblies and the Gaming-Table; all of which excepting the last have now acquired such an ascendancy that no writer upon Education would venture to proscribe them— Gaming as a positive Vice must always be forbidden by prudent Instructors, and avoided by prudent men— The Directions for the Education of Daughters are very good in themselves, but not suitable to the Spirit of the present age— I also read Sermons 6. Vol 6. of the English Preacher, on the duties of
morality; and 7 and 8 on the example of Christ. These last two are by Foster, and better than the generality of these Sermons; though none of them equal to the two by Leed.

20. I had received last Evening a note from Count Romanzoff requesting me to call upon him at 11. O’Clock this morning. I accordingly went— Count Chernicheff was with him, and I was requested to wait a few minutes— Chernicheff soon after pass’d through the antichamber where I waited, and as he pass’d stop’d to ask me, if I was not about to dispatch a Courier to Paris— I suppose he knew Mr John W. Smith had come as a Courier, and expecting I should send him back wished to send something.— There were some books laying in the Chairs— A Projet pour un Code de Commerce by Boucher— A Manuscript as I conjecture, and from its folio form and magnificent red Morocco binding I conclude, a present from the author— Also two sets of Mr Rayneval’s Book de la Liberté des Mers— The Chancellor came in after a very few minutes, and told me that the Emperor had fixed upon to-morrow for his departure; that he himself should be very soon afterwards obliged to follow him, and as there might perhaps be before his return some discussions in which the interests of the United States as well as those of Russia might be involved, from his wish to defend and support both he wished to know, as far as I was informed and might think proper to confide to him, what was the precise state of the relations between the United States, and France or England, or both; and he had been the more desirous of this information before he should go, as he knew the Courier I had expected from Paris was now arrived. That some time ago Prince Kurakin had written that there was to be a Treaty between France and the United States; and that arrangements favourable to America had actually been settled in France— But lately there seemed again to be some uncertainty upon the subject, and he had seen in one of the last Journaux de l’Empire, an Article dated at Baltimore, which seemed to hold out an angry and irritated language towards the United States— I told him that since my last Conversation with him, I had received no Communication from my own Government, of a more recent date than I had then; nor had I any information from which I could infer that any change had occurred in the state of our political relations, from that in which I had then suggested to him— That with respect to France, all that I could say from the letters I had received from Mr Barlow, was, that no definitive arrangement had yet been agreed upon; and with respect to England none had taken, nor as I believed was likely to take place— I had heard that late English Newspapers contained articles of intelligence from New-York to the 14. February; and that they said Mr Foster the British Minister was in Negotiation with our Secretary of State Mr Monroe; and it was expected that a Treaty would be concluded. I could say nothing on this subject from my own Government; but my own opinion was that no such Treaty could be concluded— I was perfectly sure it could not, unless the revocation of the British Orders in Council should be one of its explicit conditions— If Mr Foster is authorized to stipulate for the revocation of the orders, a Treaty is possible— The Count asked how I thought France in that case would take it? I said I did not know; but I believed the American Government would not enquire whether France would take it well or ill. It was the right of the United States as a neutral Nation to trade with France that the American Government was bound to protect—it was denied them by the British Orders of Council, and unless restored by the revocation of those orders, I had no doubt but the United States would vindicate it by War— But I did not anticipate a Declaration of War by the United States at present. The measures that had been taken this Winter, were measures of preparation— Upon the ocean we could do nothing— If hostilities were to commence there, they must come from the part of England, and not from ours— To attack the British upon our Continent we must be prepared— A Bill for raising 25000 men had been passed by Congress. They must be raised by voluntary enlistment for we had no system of conscription. It was a difficult, and slow work to raise, organize and discipline 25000 men— I did not think it could be done in less time than the present year; nor should we commit the folly of commencing or declaring War before we could do something to maintain it.— But unless the orders in Council were revoked, a War eventually must be their result— Did I think it probable they would be revoked?— No—every present prospect was to the contrary— I thought their existence now depended solely upon that of Mr Perceval as prime Minister in England?— Did I think Mr Perceval would remain Prime Minister?— I believed he would— Was it not probable the Marquis of Wellesley would come in again; after the Catholic question shall be disposed of?— I thought not— But how was it possible that the English Regent should be so fascinated (said the Count) by Mr Perceval, un homme a ce qu’il me parait, assez Mediocre, in preference to Wellesley, whose Career has been so much more brilliant, and who appears to have rendered real services to the Nation— A man especially so important to the affairs in Spain?— I said I had my suspicions that the Catholic question was little more than the ostensible cause of Lord Wellesley’s retirement, and that a much more efficacious real cause, was the state itself of affairs in Spain.
But how so?— There was a good deal of misunderstanding between the British Government, and that of the Spaniards at Cadix.— It had already proceeded so far that the English had threatened to abandon them— Lord Wellesley must before this time have strong misgivings about the ultimate issue of their Cause in Spain— He may be glad to retire from his particular stake upon it, while it has yet the shew, of being unimpaired— The Count said he thought it very probable and that the motive would be a very rational one— I then asked him if he expected very soon to leave the City?— Very shortly—within two or three days— The Emperor had finally resolved to go, and review the situation of his army on the frontiers— He should very shortly send me a written notice that during his absence, the business of the Department of foreign Affairs would again be entrusted to Count Soltikoff, as it had been heretofore— A person of great merit; and very deserving of the choice the Emperor had fixed upon him— I said that I could not but regret his the Chancellor’s own absence, and wish that it might be short; but that if that must be, it would have been impossible for any appointment of the Emperor’s choice to have fallen upon a person whom I esteemed and respected more than Count Soltikoff, or with whom it would be more agreeable to me to have the usual official relations— He said that his own departure was necessary; though he regretted it much; and he intimated that his advice had been not to go— But the Emperor had decided otherwise— The forces which were assembled on the frontiers, were immense— On both sides— There was in History, scarcely any thing like it.— It was like Romance— What it would come to he knew not— That perpetual restlessness and agitation of the Emperor Napoleon, was such that it was impossible to say how it would terminate— And the most extraordinary of all was that there was no Cause of War.— On the part of this Country, the affair of the Duchy of Oldenburg was the only object— Russia had made a Declaration in that case reserving her rights, but in that very Declaration had explicitly stated that she did not consider it as a cause for renouncing the Alliance or for changing the course of her policy.— I said that from the late Report of the Duke of Bassano to the Emperor Napoleon, it would seem that the principles assumed by France, went to a total exclusion of all Commerce from the Country of her friends, as the English orders of Council went to a total exclusion of all commerce from France itself— But, said the Count a total exclusion of all Commerce is impossible— You might as well set up a total exclusion of all air to breathe, or all food to subsist upon, from a whole Nation, as a total exclusion of Commerce— You must have Commerce in some shape— Either lawful and regular, or by contraband, and licences.— The system of licences is founded upon falsehood and immorality— A Sovereign who countenances such vices is no longer a sovereign— It is a virtual abdication of his authority— He is a sovereign for that very purpose to maintain justice and morality— And to give his sanction to falsehood and injustice, is in substance ceasing to reign— I urged this very argument to the Emperor in a case of individual concernment, but which in principle I consider as exactly resembling this practice of navigating by licences— On that occasion the Emperor did me signal Justice— The person particularly interested was incensed against me to extreme bitterness, but as he appears now altogether to have forgotten it, and treats me in a friendly manner, I can without impropriety mention his name. It is Count Alexis Razumofsky. (N.B. this man is the Minister of Public Instruction—the Superintendent of the Schools, Universities, and scientific Academies throughout the Empire.) the Count is upon bad terms with his wife; and has for several years lived with a woman of low Condition; a French woman; by whom he has several children, who have received letters of nobility; which is very well— But Count Rasumoffsky sometime ago wrote a letter to a friend of his, saying that he would give to a certain public University a sum of one or perhaps two hundred thousand Rubles; if letters of Nobility could be obtained for this woman. This letter was laid before the Emperor, who merely referred it to the Council; under its former organization, to report their opinion upon it— Every member of the Council was for complying with the proposition, and I saw the moment when it was about to succeed— I could not withstand the force of my impressions, and wrote to the Emperor, that the open sanction of the Sovereign to a public scandal, bargained for money; letters of nobility, sold notoriously to a woman of ill-fame, appeared to me inconsistent with the very nature of Supreme Power— The establishment and protection of virtue and morality was the very essence of Sovereignty; and to set them at such open defiance was equivalent to a renunciation of dominion itself— To illustrate my idea I further urged that if the Sovereign sold his favourable distinctions to vice, he surely could not refuse to sell his refusal of it to virtue; and I put the case as a supposition, that Countess Razumofsky, in opposition to her husband’s proposal, should offer to the same University, double the sum that he had been willing to give, to ennoble his mistress, upon condition that his request should be rejected—and I asked what figure the Council would make in deliberating between the two propositions. It resolved itself into the famous sale of indulgences by the Romish Church, under which all the most infamous crimes might be
committed at a regular and settled price.— The Emperor read my remonstrance, and told me that I had given him such a lesson of his duties that the pen had fallen from his hand— He could not accept the proposition of Count Razumofsky; and it was accordingly rejected— Now the system of formally proscribing commerce in general terms, and then allowing it by a sale of special licences, appeared to him to be of the same nature, as it would be to sell indulgences for crimes, or letters of nobility to infamy— I concurred entirely in this opinion; but observed that it was the English who had set the first example of this political profligacy, which he said was true. But by which party soever practiced it was equally scandalous and unjustifiable. He then spoke to me of this Mr Smith, who had lately arrived as a Courier, to me, and who I observed to him had been ill on the road, and was yet, I feared, very dangerously so— The Count smiled, and said he had understood that he was on the contrary in very good health, and had brought with him a fair companion— I said I had transiently heard that he travelled in company with a lady; but I knew not whether she was fair or ugly; and had supposed she was merely a traveling companion— Mr Smith was certainly not in a condition of health to indulge himself much with a fair one. The Count said he had mentioned the Circumstance to me, because he did not know how the woman had procured her Passport, or whether she had come in, as included in that of Mr Smith— That she was a woman well known here, and of no reputable character— She had been the mistress of many persons— Among the rest of a certain Coll: Duponthon who had been here with the French Ambassador, and whom she had inveigled into a determination and promise to marry her. This affair had made a great noise, and on account of it she had been obliged to leave this Country— As she was a woman of suspicious character, and the time of her returning here was somewhat critical, the Count wished to know, whether her coming with Mr Smith was merely from politeness on his part, or whether it was the consequence of an attachment— If Mr Smith had brought her with him as his friend, it was a matter with which the Government had no concern, and which would require from them no further notice; but if there was no such connection, and she had come from other motives, it would be necessary to have an eye upon her. I told the Count that I could not speak on the subject with certainty, but I would immediately obtain the information, and let him know— He said he would ask Mr Borel to call upon me, and I could mention to him the result of my enquiries which would save the trouble of writing.— I asked the Count if he should expedite a Courier to Paris before he left the City— He said he should not; but doubtless immediately after the Emperor’s arrival at Wilna he should, and if I wished to write and would send my dispatch to Count Soltykoff it would be forwarded to him and he would take care of it— He also offered to send any letter for me by a Courier going to Sweden— I left the Count, and after returning home a few minutes went and called upon Mr Smith; I found him at Walbezky’s and complaining that he was still very ill. Mr Ingraham and Mr Plummer were with him; and Mr Harris came in while I was there— I mentioned to Mr Smith in private the notice which the Government had taken of his travelling companion, and the enquiries to which she had given rise— He said that he had never seen her untill two days before he left Paris— That after he had his Passport and was preparing to depart, his servant Victor, (the same who went with Mr Jones and Mr Gray from this place to France) had told him there was a Lady of respectable character, who had her husband here, and wished to come to St: Petersburg.— She was to pay an equal part of the expence of the Journey, and the motive of saving 400 Dollars to Coll: Thorndike induced Mr Smith to consent to take her— The next day Victor expressed a doubt whether she had any money to pay for her journey, but Mr Smith ascribed that to Victor’s unwillingness to ride outside of the Carriage. Mr Smith was hesitating about what to do, untill a friend of his, a Mr Rumilly, who lodged at the same Hotel, offered, though himself a total stranger himself to the Lady, to go with him and see her. (Jones more than once mentioned this Mr Rumilly to me, and told me he had been extremely intimate with General Armstrong, while he was in France; hinting at the same time that Rumilly was secretly a Plenipotentiary of the Police Department of Paris.) They went accordingly; the Lady agreed to pay and actually paid him in advance 1200 francs, and referred him for her character to Prince Kurakin, and the Russian Embassy— She had a Passport from Prince Kurakin, entirely separate from that of Mr Smith— The Prince himself only said to Mr Smith in English, she is very pretty; but the Secretary of the Embassy, of whom he made his enquiries told him she was a respectable woman— He was however now extremely mortified at his having consented to take her, for he had now reason to believe and had heard she was not a respectable woman— To him she had been as sacred as if she had been a Princess— He had always prided himself upon the regularity of his moral character— His business here was such as required that the Government should have at least no personal indisposition towards him and he saw that his reputation would suffer from his having had this woman in company with him— Unfortunately they had been great part of the way from Berlin here travelling also in company with Countess Liewen, the wife of the Russian Minister at Berlin, who was returning home; and she had repeatedly seen this woman— She is an Italian, named Giuliani. I told Mr Smith that I should explain the Circumstances, in the manner as he had stated them to me— That the light in which it was viewed by the Government was totally different from that which affected him— Their notice was attracted by political suspicions, and they would have paid no more
attention to it, if the Lady had come only as his particular friend— He was very anxious that they might be rightly informed in this respect; but said the Lady still owed him about 300 rubles which he hoped still to receive from her— I advised him then to get it as soon as he could; for I thought it not improbable she might have occasion shortly to return whence she came— I paid a visit to Mr Laval, whom I found in deep affliction— He has within these few days lost a child— His second Son—a boy about 6 1/2 years old.— I did very warmly sympathize with him— It was a favourite child, to a man most affectionate to all his children. He told me it was impossible to conceive the feelings of the moment, when the lurking hopes, that still cling to the heart, untill the last instant of life, are all extinguished by the event—that every thing preceding is comparatively speaking pleasure— There is no supporting such Trials but by strength from above— After sitting with Mr Laval about an hour, I walked— Met and walked with Mr Woodward— In the Evening I received letters from Mr Russell, in London, and Mr Anderson at Gothenburg, both of which had been opened, and sent to me from the Post-Office, without being sealed up again.

21. This morning the Emperor Alexander went to the Church of Cazan, where he performed a solemn Act of devotion, previous to his leaving the City, to join his army on the frontiers— It was a great and aweful occasion, and I pray that his prayers for the preservation still of Peace may have been propitiated— Between one and two O’Clock he took his departure. I had morning visits from Mr Montréal and Mr Woodward— He has a letter from his brother at Liverpool, where he arrived in fifteen days from Boston— Miss Frederica Bode, dined with us— Long evening visit from Mr Harris— I walked an hour after dinner— The first time this Season— Last year I began twelve days earlier; but the difference in the advancement of the Spring is at least three weeks— I found however this Evening the passages for carriages and sleighs to the river all barr’d— The thaw though scarcely begun, has been unusually rapid.

22. Dined with Mr Harris, in company with admiral and General Tchichagoff and his brother the General, Prince Kurakin, the son of the late Minister of the Interior, Count Moussin-Pouschkin, Mr A. Severin, Mr Krehmer, and some other Gentlemen— I promised Mr Severin to go and see his collection of Medals next Saturday at 2 O’Clock— I paid a long Evening visit to the Chevalier Bezerra— Count Löwenhielm came in while I was there— Afterwards I went to Madame Colombi’s where the Ladies had pass’d the Evening— There was Company there—and Music, with the Harp and Piano, accompanied by Mr Brandel on the Violin.— When I returned home I found an official notification from Count Romanzoff, that he was going away, to accompany the Emperor, who was going for the ordinary review of his troops, and the inspection of some of his Provinces, and that in the interval Count Alexander Soltykoff, was charged with the direction of the Department of foreign Affairs— Mr Bezerra and Count Löwenhielm were commenting on the phrase that the Emperor was going for the ordinary review of his troops— Löwenhielm asked me what could be the motive of a great Court to lie for nothing?— I told him it was the power of habit—the Count had just observed that he was much attached to regular habits, and that it was better to have bad habits than none at all.

23. Answered this morning Count Romanzoff’s official Note, and paid him a visit of leave-taking, but he was not at home— I called also at Count Alexander Soltykoff’s door, and left Cards— He was not at home. I walked twice, the round through the Nefsky Perspective down the Fontanka, and along the Quay of the Neva— Before and after dinner— In the morning I met the French Ambassador who turned and walked with me; and with whom I had a long and free Conversation upon political subjects. He does not yet talk of leaving the City— Prevost goes as a Courier to-morrow, and next week he sends another.— He told me that Count Romanzoff had assured him the Emperor was gone pour empêcher ses Généraux de faire des sottises. That is, by committing any imprudence which might provoke a commencement of hostilities— I said it was strange that such a War should begin while both parties were protesting there was no Cause for War between them— He said that the chances undoubtedly were high, that the War would break out, but he could not abandon all hope that some arrangement might be concluded— That he was sure at least the Emperor Napoleon would not leave Paris untill the last of April; but the greatest danger of War arose from the obstinate refusal here to come to any explanations. I told him that the principles asserted in the Duke of Bassano’s late Report to the Emperor Napoleon, were such that if pursued in their rigour they must produce War— Their effect would be the total annihilation of the trade to the Baltic— Swedish and Russian— This it was impossible they should agree to— Neither of the Governments could accomplish it— No Government could accomplish it— France and England were perfectly agreed in the theory, of excluding all Commerce between each other— And yet both were compelled to admit it again by the means of licences— He said, therefore it was that Russia ought to come into some explanations on the subject— The principle undoubtedly was as laid down by the Duke of Bassano— But Russia might insist upon exceptions and relaxations which she might shew to be necessary— So might Sweden— France would no doubt accede to such of these as should be reasonable. The object merely was to discuss, and not substitute obstinacy, or temper in the place of reason— He told me the adventure of Longuerue, whom he sent off as a Courier, and
and who on the last Stage before he arrived at Riga, fired pistols at two Carriages successively, which were going the same way, and the drivers of which attempted to pass him. The first was a merchant, Mr Amburger, and it was said one of his horses was wounded— The second was a Courier of the Russian Government, who pushed on, in spite of the pistol shot, which Longuerue said he had fired in the air— The Courier however had complained of him at Riga, and Longuerue on his arrival went to the Governor Prince Labanoff— He said to justify himself that by the usage, nobody could pass by a Courier— This was to be sure the usage in France; but it did not follow it was the usage here— Prince Labanoff hesitated for a moment whether he should not stop Longuerue; but he did not— And the Emperor who knew it would mortify him (the Ambassador) and forbidden that any notice should be taken of it to him— So that for more than a week the Ambassador had disbelieved the whole Story— It had mortified him beyond all expression— He had not only utterly disavowed Longuerue’s conduct, but declared that it was in direct opposition to his Instructions, which were that he should conduct himself with peculiar reserve and discretion upon the road— He had sent Longuerue off, by the Emperor’s knowledge and approbation, immediately after a long Conversation the Emperor had had with him, and for the purpose of reporting it to his Government.— And he was the more vexed at Longuerue’s foolish adventure; because it had placed him, the Ambassador (Longuerue is his nephew) under the appearance of owing obligations to them here— I told him I had heard so many reports about Longuerue’s being arrested on his way &c— that I had disbelieved them all— We also talked about Sweden, and I told him there was but one way of explaining her present situation and accounting for her conduct to my Mind— When I saw a French man, a French General, a family relation of the Emperor Napoleon, taking such a decisive part against France, the only possible way of explaining it was, by observing the harshness with which France treated every foreign Nation negotiating with her— The total disregard to their interests and feelings, the perpetual sentiment of her own strength to which she resorted, left it impossible for any person in another Government to be her friend— She did so every where— We had experience of it in our own Country— He said that Subjects were treated no better than foreigners— But I must own the Prince of Ponte Corvo, or Prince Royal of Sweden, was un peu Bouillon too— Un peu Bouillon, (he did not say Brouillon) and his adventure at Vienna was a proof of it— That I told him, they ought not to reproach him with— Why not? said he— It was a great indiscretion—an Imprudence—and has always been so considered in France as well as elsewhere— Supposing I should do such a thing here now—what would you call it?— I certainly should not consider it as very prudent— Well said he—Bernadotte had no Instructions for what he did at Vienna— He did it of his own head; and it is a proof that he is un peu Bouillon— The Ambassador took in perfect good humour all the remarks I made, upon the harshness of the french Negotiations, though I expressed myself in terms as strong as could with decorum be used—we parted very amicably— The Ladies spent the Evening with Madame Bezerra.

24. Morning visits from Mr Fisher and Mr Ingraham— I settled an account with Fisher, which has been standing in part ever since last Summer— Walked before and after dinner— Received between nine and ten O’Clock in the Evening a note from Madame Bezerra, with information of an opportunity to send letters to England— But the Gentleman was to go this Night; and the dispatches must be sent by 11. O’Clock. I had therefore just time to seal up mine; in a packet for Mr Russell in London, which Mr Smith took to the Chevalier Bezerra’s— The person going is Mr Zea, the partner of the House of Colombi.

25. Mr J. W. Smith called on me this morning, and expressed some anxiety to know the result of the enquiries respecting the Lady who came with him from Paris— I told him that not having heard any further enquiry since I saw him, I concluded the Government was satisfied with the information they had obtained and would give him and themselves no more trouble about it— I called upon Mr Andrew Severin by appointment, after having by a mistake of the Servant’s been to Mr Kocheleff’s. It was the second time he had made the mistake— On the former occasion Mr Kocheleff had not received me; and a card being left, which I thought was for Mr Severin, he had enquired of Mr Bezerra, who was well acquainted with him, whether it had not been by mistake— I had told Mr Bezerra it was, but I new not how— This day Mr Kocheleff received me, and it was only on meeting him that I discovered the mistake— He appeared rather more ruffled at the accident than I thought necessary— I made an apology to him for the blunders of my servant, which he did not receive with much courtesy.
When I finally found out Mr Severin’s I spent about two hours with him examining his collection of Russian Coins.— He has them from the time of Peter the Great’s Grandfather— And a great variety of them.— He has also a large collection of foreign Coins, which were packed up, as he is about to move into another house— I therefore could not see them— He shewed me however his Cromwell’s Guinea, which looks perfectly new, and has a head of the Protector, extremely well executed, and a great likeness— The greatest curiosities of his Russian Coins are the Roubles, with the heads of Peter and Ivan on one side, and Sophia holding the Sceptre on the other; and a Ruble of Peter 3. with the head of Catherine 2. struck, over that of Peter, whose profile is still discernible upon it.— He has a Bank of England Dollar with similar remnants of the Spanish coinage apparent upon it.— He has a Ruble with the head of Paul, which he suppressed because he found it too ugly; and seven different samples of the present Emperor’s head which he never would approve—perhaps because none of them are handsome enough— There is not indeed among them one that can be called a favourable likeness— He has also a Ruble and half-imperial of Elizabeth, which she suppressed because her head was so ill executed upon it— Mr Severin invited me to come again and see other parts of his collection next Friday, which I promised to do— I walked untill dinner time— After dinner attended the sale at Hémilian’s, and made a purchase of furniture— Mr and Madame Bezerra were with us in the Evening— I read to the Ladies the first Canto of Scott’s Lady of the Lake.

26. The weather was like that usual to the month of April in mild climates— Clear and warm Sunshine in the morning; and rain in showers the remainder of the day— By the Russian Calendar it was Palm-Sunday. I walked before and after dinner— We had Evening visits from the French Ambassador, Mr Harris and Mr Woodward— I read the Remnants of Time in Prose and Verse, by Watts; published with his Improvement of the Mind— They are principally short remarks on texts of Scripture, the most curious of them is that which closes the volume; a dissertation on the form of a Cherub— They are all ingenious and with an original turn of thought— He makes religious applications of every thing— Horace’s Odes—painted Diamonds and Bills of Exchange— In the Diamond painted there is a glance at the Church of England, for retaining too many of the ceremonious formalities of Popery—the only one I have perceived in the Book.

27. Mr Borel had promised to call upon me this day, for which reason I remained at home all the morning and untill 4. O’Clock; but he did not come— In the Evening I attended at Hémilian’s— On returning home I found Mr Brandel, who spent the Evening with us— Etter brought me the copper-Plate of his Image, which he now takes to be the Scandinavian Goddess Peroun, and which he wishes to send to the American Academy as a present— He also persuaded me to come and see some of his books.

28. The ice of the river Neva broke up early this morning; having been six months complete since the Bridges were carried away at its freezing— The Bridge from the Isaac Square stood untill 3. this afternoon— Mrs Adams went out to look at the house in the Country, which Mr Strugoffschikoff proposed to me to take for the Summer—on the Peterhoff road, near Strelna— She returned, much fatigued, just before dinner. I called at Etter’s, and he prevailed upon me to take some of his books— I walked before dinner and again in the Evening— The rest of it I employed in looking over the Plates of two Volumes of Costumes of the Antient Nations; with Charles.

29. I finished reading this morning with Charles, the Fables of La Fontaine, which have furnished his regular daily reading lesson, exactly five Months— Notwithstanding the frequent interruptions occasioned by his occasional illness and my own his progress has been as favourable as I could expect, and he now reads with facility, though not yet correctly— When we returned from into the City last October he scarcely knew the letters of the Alphabet.— It was then however nearly two years since I began to teach him— I shall now begin to teach him English reading, of which he knows nothing; and resumed Berquin’s Ami des Enfans; which he can at present read with ease, and whose Stories he begins to understand— La Fontaine’s fables have served the purpose of teaching him to read, better than any other book I had, because the Edition I have used has a wooden Cut, before every Fable which has proved a lure to his curiosity and attention. But there are very few of them, which he could understand at all, and the less he has understood the more difficult I have found it to fix his attention. I had never regularly read through myself before, the twelve Books of this Fabulist, whom the French Critics extol as the most perfect writer of Fables, of any age or Nation— There is a mixture of careless simplicity, and shrewd sagacity, of indulgent good-humour and sly severity, of vulgar phraseology; and elevated poetical beauty
which perhaps no other fabulist possesses in so high a degree, and which are peculiarly adapted to this particular species of writing— His versification is negligent and seldom harmonious— But that also is excusable for these popular unpretending Stories, written for children, and for the ignorant— He has no merit of invention; for he took his subjects from any body; even from the Duke de Bourgogne, a child, of eight years old— The point in which he appears most deficient is precisely that which I deem the most essential— I mean the morality— It is either the old, and hacknied moral of his predecessors from whom he takes the story; or a half-indulged and half-suppressed Satire upon kings, nobles and Priests (which I believe more than everything else has contributed to his excessive reputation in France;) or frequent repetition of common place axioms—or inconsistencies with himself—or finally and worst of all, questionable or false principles— Examples of all these defects might easily be adduced; nor would the number be small of feeble and insignificant conclusions, not worthy of a story built upon them.— La Fontaine in short teaches very little virtue of any kind; and perhaps more vice than virtue—of elevated or heroic Virtue, he seems not to have had a conception— His great merit is as a story-teller and not as a moralist— The two Pigeons for instance has a false moral— Its doctrine is; never travel for improvement; because you may meet with disasters and may be separated from your friend or lover— But it is full of charming strokes of tenderness and affection— Not conjugal affection; for the pigeons are brothers— Nor yet fraternal affection, for the Poet applies himself his moral to happy lovers—boasts how much he has loved once; and laments that he is too old to love again— It is therefore licentious love that he substantially recommends; and he has expressly and unnaturally avoided to make his pigeons mates, lest it should be mistaken for a case of marriage— He was tormented it is said with a termagant wife— And he expressly disavows all respect for marriage— He disavows too paternal affection; and according to an anecdote related of him, did not know his own son, when introduced to him, at twenty-five years of age.— He is said to have died profoundly penitent for his tales, which are indeed much more grossly licentious than his fables, but which perhaps do not shew more moral laxity of mind— His flattery of Louis XIV. of the Dauphin; the Duke de Bourgogne, the Prince de Conti, and even of Madame de Montespan, may be excused; for when you are obliged to say “let Horace blush, and Virgil too,” it would be requiring too much of La Fontaine, not to let him pass in the throng— On the whole therefore La Fontaine is the first of Story-tellers, but not of fabulists— As to his famous two Pigeons; Moores “Sparrow and Dove[”] may be placed in opposition to it, and in my estimation would bear the palm from it in every respect— I walked morning and Evening— Catherine spent the Eve at Madame Colombi’s. I received from Count Soltikoff a packet brought by a Courier from Paris— Only a short letter from Mr Barlow.

30. Mr Bentzon paid me a visit this morning, and informed me that he should take his departure the day after to-morrow, for Copenhagen, whence he intended to proceed perhaps after a month’s residence there, to America. He offered to take letters for me; which I am accordingly preparing— I began regularly with Charles to read Dufief’s Grammar, and Berquin’s Ami des Enfans.— The first for English and French Phrases; the other for the reading and the Stories— I walked morning and Evening; after which I amused him with the cyphered Circles— Met and walked with Mr Saltus on my Evening walk.

Day. As the Season advances, I find it more and more impracticable to close my Evenings before Midnight; and often later— I therefore do not rise in the morning earlier than seven or eight.— My employments continue regular— Reading 5 Chapters in the French Bible— Writing Journal, or idling away an hour untill ten— Breakfast— Give Charles his lessons, receive visitors, attend to the occasional calls of household affairs, and read or write, untill 3 or 4— Walk an hour before and an hour after dinner; and give the short Evenings to visitors, Charles and the Ladies— My walks before Breakfast are suspended— I find time neither for writing nor reading so much as I wish.
